docs.snippet: A Rwandan wanted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal on genocide charges flew to Arusha, Tanzania, to turn himself in to the court there, the Italian diocese that has sheltered him announced. The Rev. Athanase Seromba, 38, has lived in the F...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Rwandan wanted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal on genocide charges flew to Arusha, Tanzania, to turn himself in to the court there, the Italian diocese that has sheltered him announced. The Rev. Athanase Seromba, 38, has lived in the Florence diocese since 1997. According to the group African Rights, Father Seromba fled his parish in western Rwanda in June 1994, ''leaving behind him mass graves filled with more than 2,000 bodies.''
docs.abstract: Rev Athanase Seromba, Rwandan wanted by United Nations war crimes tribunal on genocide charges flies to Arusha, Tanzania, to turn himself in to court there; has been sheltered in Italian diocese of Florence since 1997 (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Priest Surrenders To Tribunal

docs.snippet: The ethnic Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, suffered a major setback in his bid for the Kosovo presidency today, twice failing to win enough support in the province's new legislature.    The outcome keeps Kosovo without a president or a government...
docs.lead_paragraph: The ethnic Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, suffered a major setback in his bid for the Kosovo presidency today, twice failing to win enough support in the province's new legislature. The outcome keeps Kosovo without a president or a government almost two months after a historic election that was intended to create substantial self-rule under the United Nations umbrella.
docs.abstract: Ethnic Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, suffers major setback in his bid for Kosovo presidency, twice failing to win enough support in province's new legislature; outcome keeps Kosovo without president or government almost two months after historic election intended to create substantial self-rule under United Nations umbrella (S)

headline.main: Kosovo Leader Fails In Repeated Efforts To Become President

docs.snippet: Jean-Pierre Bemba, leader of Uganda-backed rebels who control about a third of Congo, said he would boycott peace talks next week in South Africa. At a news conference in Paris, he said he objected to the selection of political foes who will take ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jean-Pierre Bemba, leader of Uganda-backed rebels who control about a third of Congo, said he would boycott peace talks next week in South Africa. At a news conference in Paris, he said he objected to the selection of political foes who will take part. The so-called Inter-Congolese Dialogue is supposed to bring together representatives from the government and the political and armed opposition, and other leaders. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
docs.abstract: Jean-Pierre Bemba, leader of Uganda-backed rebels who control about one-third of Congo, says he will boycott scheduled peace talks in South Africa because of selection of political foes who will take part (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Rebel May Boycott Talks

docs.snippet: A Chilean guerrilla engineered the kidnapping of a Brazilian advertising executive who was rescued over the weekend after nearly two months in captivity, the police said today.    The guerrilla, Mauricio Hernández Norambuena, who was arrested on ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Chilean guerrilla engineered the kidnapping of a Brazilian advertising executive who was rescued over the weekend after nearly two months in captivity, the police said today. The guerrilla, Mauricio Hernández Norambuena, who was arrested on Friday in Brazil, was behind the abduction of Washington Olivetto, said Godofredo Bittencourt, head of São Paulo's Organized Crime Division.
docs.abstract: Mauricio Hernandez Norambuena, Chilean guerrilla, is arrested by police in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and charged with engineering kidnapping of Washington Olivetto, Brazilian advertising executive who was held for nearly two months before his rescue (S)

headline.main: Chilean Leftist Is Held in Brazil Kidnapping

docs.snippet: An unexploded World War II bomb found buried beneath the lower ring of seats of Olympic Stadium in Berlin was defused by explosives experts, the police said. The 550-pound British bomb was found during renovation work. The 76,000-seat stadium, des...
docs.lead_paragraph: An unexploded World War II bomb found buried beneath the lower ring of seats of Olympic Stadium in Berlin was defused by explosives experts, the police said. The 550-pound British bomb was found during renovation work. The 76,000-seat stadium, designed by the Nazi architect Albert Speer for the 1936 Olympics, is being overhauled for the 2006 World Cup soccer tournament. Victor Homola (NYT)
docs.abstract: Unexploded World War II bomb is found buried beneath lower rung of seats of Olympic Stadium in Berlin, Germany; 550-pound British bomb is defused by explosives experts (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Old Bomb Found In Berlin

docs.snippet: JAN SVERAK, the director of ''Dark Blue World,'' was 10 when he learned about the Czech pilots who fought on the side of the Allies during World War II. The memory is vivid. He was home from school, sick in bed with the flu, and his father gave hi...
docs.lead_paragraph: JAN SVERAK, the director of ''Dark Blue World,'' was 10 when he learned about the Czech pilots who fought on the side of the Allies during World War II. The memory is vivid. He was home from school, sick in bed with the flu, and his father gave him a book about them. ''When you are having a fever and reading about night raids over Germany, you keep dreaming about it afterward,'' said Mr. Sverak, 36, during a recent visit to New York. He recalled one story in particular, about a pilot who was ''shot down over France, onto a farm, and the French people gave him food and clothing.''
docs.abstract: Nancy Ramsey article on Czech director Jan Sverak, whose latest film Dark Blue World, starring Tara Fitzgerald and Ondrej Vetchyher, is about his and his father's childhood heroes: Czech pilots who fought on side of Allies during World War II; photo (M)

headline.main: Film; A Czech Director Salutes His Heroes

docs.snippet: Philippine troops have clashed several times in the last week with Muslim rebels holding an American missionary couple hostage, leading to suggestions here that an attempt to rescue the couple from the remote jungle island of Basilan may be immine...
docs.lead_paragraph: Philippine troops have clashed several times in the last week with Muslim rebels holding an American missionary couple hostage, leading to suggestions here that an attempt to rescue the couple from the remote jungle island of Basilan may be imminent. The couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham, and their captors, the Abu Sayyaf, became a focus of the Bush administration's war on terror when President Bush sent 600 American soldiers, including 160 Special Forces troops, to the Philippines in January to train its troops to eliminate the guerrillas and free the hostages.
docs.abstract: Philippine troops clash several times in last week with Muslim rebels holding American missionary couple Martin and Graciela Burnham hostage, leading to suggestions that attempt to rescue couple from remote jungle island of Basilan may be imminent; map (M)

headline.main: Philippine Clashes May Point to Attempt to Rescue American Hostages From Rebels

docs.snippet: The prime minister of Sri Lanka and the reclusive leader of separatist Tamil rebels signed a formal cease-fire agreement today that is expected to lead to the first peace talks between the warring parties in seven years.    The cease-fire, which b...
docs.lead_paragraph: The prime minister of Sri Lanka and the reclusive leader of separatist Tamil rebels signed a formal cease-fire agreement today that is expected to lead to the first peace talks between the warring parties in seven years. The cease-fire, which begins on Saturday, brings the promise of a respite from an 18-year-old ethnic conflict that has claimed more than 60,000 lives on the island nation off the southern tip of India. Norway, which brokered the deal, will lead an international mission to monitor the cease-fire on the ground.
docs.abstract: Prime Min Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka signs formal cease-fire agreement with Tamil leader Velupillai Prabhakaran that is expected to lead to first peace talks between warring parties in seven years; truce brings promise of respite from 18-year-old ethnic conflict that has claimed more than 60,000 lives; Norway, which brokered deal, will lead international mission to monitor cease-fire on ground; Prime Min Jan Petersen of Norway hails accord as bold step toward peace, but also seeks to discourage unrealistic hopes of quick resolution to one of world's most intractable civil wars (M)

headline.main: Truce Accord In Sri Lanka Could Herald Peace Talks

docs.snippet: A former Rwandan Catholic priest charged with involvement in the genocidal massacres of 1994 has been arrested in Cameroon and will be transferred to a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, the Internews agency said today.     The former priest, Ho...
docs.lead_paragraph: A former Rwandan Catholic priest charged with involvement in the genocidal massacres of 1994 has been arrested in Cameroon and will be transferred to a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, the Internews agency said today. The former priest, Hormisdas Nsengimana, 48, was a rector in Butare province in southwestern Rwanda and is accused of playing a leading role in the killing of ethnic Tutsi in the province. He was arrested on Thursday, the news agency said, and faces charges of genocide, conspiracy to commit genocide and crimes against humanity.
docs.abstract: Hormisdas Nsengimana, former Rwandan Catholic priest charged in 1994 genocidal massacres, is arrested in Cameroon and will be transferred to UN tribunal in Tanzania (S)

docs.snippet: A few weeks before ordering an escalation of the Vietnam War, President Nixon matter-of-factly raised the idea of using a nuclear bomb. His national security adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, quickly dissuaded him.    Mr. Nixon's abrupt suggestion, bur...
docs.lead_paragraph: A few weeks before ordering an escalation of the Vietnam War, President Nixon matter-of-factly raised the idea of using a nuclear bomb. His national security adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, quickly dissuaded him. Mr. Nixon's abrupt suggestion, buried in 500 hours of tapes released today at the National Archives, came after Mr. Kissinger had presented a variety of options for stepping up the war effort, among them attacking power plants and docks, in an April 25, 1972, conversation in the Executive Office Building in Washington.
docs.abstract: Tapes released at National Archives show that Pres Richard M Nixon matter-of-factly raised idea of using nuclear bomb in Vietnam War in 1972, but was quickly dissuaded by his national security adviser Henry A Kissinger; few weeks later, Nixon ordered biggest escalation of war since 1968 (S)

headline.main: Nixon Proposed Using A-Bomb In Vietnam War
